title-group.article-title: Taxonomic study on Afrotropical Osoriinae (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae). Status of Mimogonellus Fagel and Madegassosorius Scheerpeltz

kwd.tp:taxon-name: Md. robustus Coiffait and Md. sogai Coiffait
Madegassosorius keiseri Scheerpeltz, and Peter Hlaváč

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Taxonomic study on Afrotropical Osoriinae ( Coleoptera : Staphylinidae ). Status of
Mimogonellus Fagel
and
Madegassosorius Scheerpeltz
MATEUSZ SAPIEJA 1, 2* & PAWEŁ JAŁOSZYŃSKI 1, 3

1
Museum of Natural History, University of Wrocław, Sienkiewicza 21, 50-335 Wrocław, Poland

2
Ễ
thoracophorus@yahoo.com ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0003-1151-4245

3
Ễ
scydmaenus@yahoo.com ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0003-2973-1803

* Corresponding author:
Ễ thoracophorus@yahoo.com

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
Among Afrotropical genera of Osoriini ,
Madegassosorius Scheerpeltz
is exceptionally poorly defined. Although later authors maintained this genus, they restricted its diagnostic features and distinguish it from the apparently highly similar
Mimogonellus Fagel
merely by the structure or presence of the lateral pronotal carinae and the elytral adsutural striae. A comprehensive survey of specimens belonging to most world genera of Osoriini suggested that these characters may be variable within the genus and therefore of weak taxonomic value. In order to test this hypothesis, the type species of
Madegassosorius
and
Mimogonellus
were studied in detail, as well as dozens of additional specimens belonging to this unclearly defined group. As a result,
Madegassosorius
syn. n.
is placed as a junior synonym of
Mimogonellus
, and the latter genus is redefined and redescribed. A lectotype is designated for
Mimogonus leleupi Cameron
, the type species of
Mimogonellus
. The synonymization of
Madegassosorius
with
Mimogonellus
results in one case of secondary homonymy, and
Mimogonellus longipennides
nom. n.
is proposed as a replacement name for
Mimogonellus longipennis ( Coiffait, 1979 )
comb. n.
(ex
Madegassosorius
), nec
Mimogonellus longipennis Fagel, 1960
.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Key words: taxonomy ,
Osoriini
,
new synonym , new combination
,
Madagascar

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Based on
,
,
), there are several genera among the Afrotropical members of the tribe Osoriini that share many external characters and are difficult to distinguish. This group includes
Euparagonus Fagel, 1955
(=
Paragonus Fauvel, 1895
),
Gigarthrus Bernhauer, 1915
,
Madegassosorius Scheerpeltz, 1961
,
Mimogonellus Fagel, 1955
,
Mimogonidius Fagel, 1959
,
Mimogonoderus Fagel, 1969
,
Mimogonus Fauvel, 1903
,
Saegerius Fagel, 1955
, and
Thoracogonus Coiffait, 1979
. All these genera share the lateral pronotal margins more or less abruptly narrowing in the posterior half, strongly converging towards the pronotal base. Some of them may be separate genera, and some may in fact be defined by characters of too weak taxonomic value to justify their current status. The most problematic pair of this assemblage is
Mimogonellus
and
Madegassosorius
, and our preliminary attempts to unambiguously place many Afrotropical specimens in either of these genera failed.

According to
,
Mimogonellus
(in addition to the abovementioned pronotal structure) is characterized by: (1) moniliform antennae with antennomeres 4‒10 subglobose, and 11 slightly longer than 10 in both sexes; (2) the pronotum lacking dorsal basolateral impressions; (3) the outer margin of the fore tibia bearing distinct spines; and (4) the aedeagus with long parameres.
Madegassosorius
, which seems to highly resemble
Mimogonellus
judging from the habitus illustration in
: fig. 1), was compared by its author only to the relatively dissimilar
Afrosorius Fagel, 1955
and
Osorius Guérin-Méneville, 1829
, but in fact his description does not contain a diagnosis that could be used to identify the new genus. The only comparative remark refers to the mandibular structure, and is highly problematic: “
Mundteile im wesentlichen mit jenen von Osorius Latreille beziehungsweise Afrosorius Fagel übereinstimmend, aber die Mandibeln wie bei der letztgenannten Gattung am Innerrande gezähnelt, vor der Spitze mit einem kleinen Zahn
” (i.e., mouthparts essentially corresponding to those of
Osorius
and
Afrosorius
, respectively, but the mandibles, as in the latter genus, toothed on the inner margin, with a small tooth before the tip). All remaining characters given in the description were not compared with features of any Osoriinae . It is clear, however, from the illustrated bizarre modification of the abdominal apex, especially the tergite X, that
Madegassosorius
is only remotely similar to
Osorius
and
Afrosorius
, as the two latter genera have unmodified abdominal apices. A similar modification of tergite X was earlier illustrated for
Mimogonellus
, e.g., by
, and this feature is common among the several genera listed in the introduction. Scheerpeltz’s hypothesis of the separate status of
Madegassosorius
was questioned by
, who discussed the distribution of
Mimogonellus
and mentioned, without any firm arguments, that
Madegassosorius
may be its junior synonym. The first author who attempted to discuss differences between these two genera was
, who in his key to the Malagasy osoriine genera gave some distinguishing characters.According to him,
Madegassosorius
has entire lateral pronotal carinae reaching posterior pronotal angles, in contrast to
Mimogonellus
, which has the lateral pronotal carinae always interrupted before the base by a smooth basal concavity, and therefore not reaching the posterior pronotal margin. Moreover,
also points out that
Madegassosorius
can be distinguished from
Mimogonellus
by the absence of the adsutural elytral striae. Both features require verification.

Examination of dozens of identified and unidentified specimens of both genera from Madagascar , continental Africa, Thailand , and Japan revealed that original descriptions and differentiating characters discussed by later authors, e.g., those given by
, are not sufficient to unambiguously assign species either to
Madegassosorius
or to
Mimogonellus
. In order to clarify this long-standing problem, a detailed study of the type species of
Madegassosorius
and
Mimogonellus
was carried out. As a result,
Mimogonellus
is redescribed, and the separate status of
Madegassosorius
is rejected based on morphological evidence.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: Depositories
NHMW—Natural History Museum, Vienna , Austria (H. Schillhammer)
RMCA—Royal Museum for Central Africa, Tervuren, Belgium (S. Hanot)

Specimens examined. The syntype series of
Mimogonus leleupi Cameron
(the type species of
Mimogonellus Fagel
), consisting of two males and one female , has been studied in detail. The male illustrated in Fig. 1 and bearing labels shown in Fig. 51 is here designated as a lectotype for
Mimogonus leleupi
( Fig. 1 ) (RMCA). A paratype male of
Madegassosorius keiseri Scheerpeltz
( Fig. 3 ) (the type species of
Madegassosorius
) (NHMW) was used for morphological study and was confirmed to be conspecific with the holotype male ( Fig. 53 ) (Natural History Museum Basel, Switzerland ), which was examined in a high-resolution habitus photo. Because of the identical initial capital letter of
Mimogonellus
and Madegass osorius, herein we use the abbreviations Mm. and Md. , respectively, when referring to various species.

Additional genera studied. In order to assess morphological variability within Osoriini , representatives of the following 43 genera were studied:
Afrosorius Fagel, 1958
,
Afrotyphlopsis Fagel, 1955
,
Allosorius Fagel, 1959
,
Arpagonus Blackwelder, 1952
,
Atopocnemius Bernhauer, 1914
,
Bacillopsis Normand, 1920
,
Bothrys Fauvel, 1895
,
Cylindrops Fagel, 1955
,
Cylindropsis Fauvel, 1885
,
Edapholotrochus Fagel, 1958
,
Euparagonus Fagel, 1955
,
Gigarthrus Bernhauer, 1915
,
Gnatholotrochus Fagel, 1955
,
Heterocylindropsis Fagel, 1955
,
Holotrochomorphus Fagel, 1955
,
Holotrochopsis Fagel, 1955
,
Holotrochus Erichson, 1839
,
Idiocnemius Cameron, 1937
,
Indosorius Coiffait, 1978
,
Kistneria Coiffait, 1967
,
Leptotyphlopsis Scheerpeltz, 1931
,
Levasseuria Coiffait, 1979
,
Lusitanopsis Coiffait, 1961
,
Madecosorius Fagel, 1959
,
Mimogonellus Fagel, 1955
(specimens coming from Australia , Japan , Madagascar , Rwanda , Tanzania , Thailand , and DR Congo ),
Mimogonia Coiffait, 1978
,
Mimogonus Fauvel, 1903
,
Molosoma Say, 1831
,
Neocaledonopsis Pace, 1990
,
Neosorius Fagel, 1959
,
Nototorchus McColl, 1985
,
Oeophronistus Blackburn, 1902
,
Oryssomma Notman, 1925
,
Osoriocanthus Fagel, 1959
,
Osoriopsis Fagel, 1955
,
Osorius Guérin-Méneville, 1829
,
Paratorchus McColl, 1985
,
Rhabdopsis Fagel, 1955
,
Saegerius Fagel, 1959
,
Tumboecus Fagel, 1959
,
Typhlholotrochus Fagel, 1955
,
Typhlobledius Lea, 1906
, and
Typhlosorius Coiffait, 1958
. Various species of these genera were loaned from the Australian National Insect Collection, CSIRO Ecosystem Sciences, Canberra, Australia (ANIC), Entomological Laboratory, Kyushu University, Fukuoka , Japan (ELKU), Institut royal des Sciences naturelles de Belgique , Brussel , Belgium (RBINS), Moravian Museum, Brno, Czech Republic (MMBC), Muséum d’histoire naturelle de la Ville de Genève , Switzerland (MHNG), and Museum für Naturkunde der Humboldt-Universität, Berlin (MNHB).

Specimen handling and imaging. Dry-mounted specimens were relaxed in warm water containing ~1% acetic acid and dissected; aedeagi and terminalia were dehydrated and deaerated in isopropanol, transferred to xylene and mounted in Canada balsam on plastic transparent cards. Habitus images and close-ups ( Figs 1‒5 ) were taken with a Canon 5D Mark II camera with a Canon MP-E 65mm f/2.8 1–5X Macro Lens, and a Canon MT-24EX Macro Twin Lite Flash used as the light source. Images of elytra, legs, abdomens and labels ( Figs 27‒34 , 41, 42 ) were taken with a Prokyon camera (Jenoptic AG, Jena, Germany ) mounted on a Nikon SMZ1500 stereoscopic microscope; transparent structures in permanent mounts ( Figs 35‒40 , 43, 44, 47, 48 ) were photographed with a Nikon D7500 camera mounted on a Nikon Eclipse Ni compound microscope. For scanning electron microscopy (SEM), beetles were mounted on a SEM stub with a carbon tab and examined as uncoated specimens using a Zeiss Auriga SEM (Jena, Germany ) ( Figs 8‒26 ). Line illustrations were made by freehand drawing. Image stacks were processed using Helicon Focus v. 8.2.0 Pro (HeliconSoft Ltd.).

kwd.tp:taxon-name: Md. robustus Coiffait and Md. sogai Coiffait

mixed-citation.named-content: Taxonomic study on Afrotropical Osoriinae (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae). Status of Mimogonellus Fagel and Madegassosorius Scheerpeltz

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Mimogonellus Fagel, 1955: 26
.

Type species:
Mimogonus leleupi Cameron, 1952
(original designation).

Revised diagnosis. Frons and vertex together transverse; head with postocular region exposed; clypeus trapezoidal with straight anterior margin; labrum symmetrical and subrectangular, strongly transverse; antennae moniliform, with subglobose antennomeres 4–10; maxillary palp 4 subconical, slightly narrowing posterad in short sub-basal region; pronotum inversely subtrapezoidal or subcordiform; notosternal sutures lacking (indistinct and superficial impressions or ridges may be present between prosternum and hypomera); tarsi 5-5-5; elytra without lateral rows of punctures; posterior margin of tergite X modified in both sexes, bearing one to several teeth on each side; aedeagus with parameres.

Redescription. Body of both sexes (
) elongate and slender, weakly flattened; pigmentation brown; dorsum sparsely setose; body length in most species 3–8 mm .

Antennae (
) moniliform, indistinctly broadening distally, composed of 11 antennomeres, of which scape, pedicel and first flagellomere elongate, 4–10 subglobose, and 11 elongate with a blunt or pointed apex. All antennomeres sparsely setose.

Elytra (
) together subrectangular; anterior elytral margin demarcated from articulating lobe by transverse impression; humeral calli weakly elevated; lateral elytral margins almost parallel and straight or weakly rounded; posterior margin of each elytron truncate, together transverse, weakly convex or weakly concave. Inner lateral margin of each elytron distinctly emarginate, with adsutural sulcus.

Aedeagus (
) elongate, distal portion of median lobe curved towards parameral side. Parameres symmetrical or nearly so, with apical setae.

Distribution. Nominal species occur in Africa, Madagascar , Laos , and Japan ; Fagel (1955) mentioned undescribed species from Sumatra and New Guinea . During the present study, specimens from Australia and Thailand were also seen.

kwd.tp:taxon-name: Md. robustus Coiffait and Md. sogai Coiffait

mixed-citation.named-content: Taxonomic study on Afrotropical Osoriinae (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae). Status of Mimogonellus Fagel and Madegassosorius Scheerpeltz

tp:treatment-sec.p:
The type species of
Madegassosorius
(illustrated in
,
,
,
,
,
,
,
,
), closely resembles the type species of
Mimogonellus
. The following characters found to be different in these species, some treated as diagnostic features for
Madegassosorius
by previous authors, are discussed below.

Shape of pronotum. The pronotal margins converging posteriorly in Osoriini provide a broad constriction between the prothorax and mesothorax, where the distal portions of profemora fit. Therefore, the shape of the pronotum is important for the mobility of the fore legs. This function is realized either by a rapid posterior narrowing (pronotum subcordiform), or simply by a graduall narrowing (pronotum inversely subtrapezoidal). Most nominal species of
Mimogonellus
have the pronotum subcordiform, so that the lateral margins are distinctly concave near base, as those in
Mm. leleupi
(
). The type species of
Madegassosorius
,
Md. keiseri
, has the pronotum inversely subtrapezoidal, with lateral margins barely noticeably sinuate. However, the pronotal shape is variable within both genera. For instance, in
Md. robustus Coiffait and Md. sogai Coiffait
, the pronota are intermediate in shape between the one in
Mm. leleupi
and
Md. keiseri
, with the basal region distinctly narrowed, but less rapidly and more shallowly than in
Mm. leleupi
. The variable shapes of pronota within
Madegassosorius
, from gradually narrowing from anterior third, to abruptly narrowed in the posterior fourth, were illustrated by Coiffait (1979 : figs 3–4). The convex vs. strongly sinuate lateral pronotal margins seem to be extreme states of a morphocline and this character cannot be used to unambiguously place species in
Mimogonellus
or
Madegassosorius
.

Lateral pronotal carinae . Coiffait (1979) used the carina to distinguish
Mimogonellus
(carinae incomplete, posteriorly obliterated because of the posterior abrupt narrowing) from
Madegassosorius
(carina complete, reaching posterior pronotal corners). In fact, the lateral pronotal margins in
Mm. leleupi
are somewhat diffuse on entire length, not forming sharp edges, in a cross-section they are rounded, not sharp-angled. In.
Md. keiseri
, the hypomera are more impressed, so that the lateral pronotal margins are slightly more distinct, and the pronotal base bears a pair of shallow lateral impressions that compress the pronotal margins near the base, forming distinct lateral carinae. However, the carinae do not correlate with the presence of the posterior abrupt narrowing, nor with the presence of the lateral antebasal impressions. For instance, in
Mm. leleupi
the lateral pronotal margins form indistinct lateral edges in front of the posterior narrowing, and within the narrowed region there are no traces of lateral edges. In
Mm. microphthalmus Fagel
( Rwanda ), with the pronotum similarly subcordiform as that in
Mm. leleupi
, the lateral pronotal margins in front of the posterior narrowing are also poorly marked, but within the narrowed region slightly diffuse edges can be seen. Such edges, in turn, are not present in
Mm. collarti Fagel
( DR Congo ), which has conspicuous antebasal lateral impressions on the pronotum. Thus, the length of the lateral pronotal carinae is also a weak taxonomic character and cannot be used to define
Madegassosorius
.

Antebasal pronotal impressions. Fagel (1955) defined
Mimogonellus
as not having lateral impressions on the pronotal base. The type species of
Madegassosorius
has such impressions, while most species of
Mimogonellus
are indeed devoid of such structures. However, Fagel himself placed in
Mimogonellus Mm. collarti
, which has two pairs of distinct antebasal impressions.

Adsutural stria/sulcus on the elytra. Coiffait (1979) mentions that
Madegassosorius
is characterized by the lack of the adsutural sulcus on each elytron, in contrast to
Mimogonellus
, which has such a structure. This sulcus demarcates a narrow elevated sutural area and is clearly present in the type species of both
Mimogonellus
and
Madegassosorius
(
).

Male sexual characters. The difference in the structure of the abdominal sternite VIII in the examined male specimens is evident (
vs 37). However, based on many examined nominal species of
Mimogonellus
, it can be concluded that the size, shape, placement and number of lateral teeth or denticles on the sternite is highly variable. In
Mm. leleupi
, the sternite VIII (
) has only tiny lateral denticles, while in
Mm. microphthalmus
,
Mm. africanus Bernhauer
and
Mm. similis Fagel
there are 6–7 pairs of teeth, not only on margins, but also on the dorsal surface. Moreover, the shape of the sternite VIII within
Mimogonellus
is variable, from subtriangular to subtrapezoidal with a truncate apex and concave posterior margin (e.g., in
Mm. similis
). Therefore, this structure and its modifications cannot be used to distinguish these genera.

As a result, we conclude that the observed differences between the type species of
Mimogonellus
and that of
Madegassosorius
reflect species-level variability within one genus.
Therefore,
Madegassosorius Scheerpeltz
, syn. n. is placed as a junior synonym of
Mimogonellus Fagel.
The resulting new combinations are as follows:

kwd.tp:taxon-name: Md. robustus Coiffait and Md. sogai Coiffait

,

; secondary homonymy in

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Among characters mentioned by
as diagnostic for
Mimogonellus
, we exclude the lack of antebasal pronotal impressions and the outer margin of the protibia bearing a row of spine-like setae. In one species,
Mm. collarti
, otherwise not differing in any particular characters from the type species of
Mimogonellus
, we found antebasal pronotal impressions, and the fore tibiae lacking the row of spines. These two characters do not seem sufficient to transfer
Mm. collarti
to a separate genus and this variation has been incorporated into the redescription of
Mimogonellus
.

The genus
Mimogonellus
can be distinguished from similar Osoriini by a relatively small number of characters, listed in the diagnosis. During the present study we did not find any apomorphies in
Mimogonellus
, and only features known to occur also in other genera of Osoriini (but in a different combination) allow for identification of
Mimogonellus
. This set of characters is most similar to those that define
Thoracogonus
and
Edapholotrochus
(see later). The externally very similar
Mimogonus
clearly differs in lacking parameres (present in
Mimogonellus
).

An interesting finding in our study is the lack of notosternal sutures in
Mimogonellus
, a character not used by previous authors focused on the Afrotropical Osorriini to diagnose genera. For this reason, the presence or lack of notosternal sutures is largely unknown within this tribe. Our preliminary research demonstrates that this structure may be important to define genera, as the notosternal sutures are clearly present, e.g., among the studied Eastern Palaearctic members of the genus
Osorius
, and absent or indistinctly marked in all other genera examined so far. In
Mimogonellus
,
Mimogonus
,
Nototrochus
and
Oryssoma
, although the sutures are entirely obliterated (in
Mimogonellus
confirmed by examination of deaerated specimens, especially teneral ones with light pigmentation, in ethanol under a compund microscope), on the surface a longitudinal groove often accentuated by a slightly convex ridge can be seen. These structures can be mistaken for notosternal sutures, but they are clearly only on the surface, not cutting through the cuticle. We refer to them as ‘false notosternal sutures’ because their origin can be composite, the impressed portion from the suture, while the accompanying ridge (visible only in some specimens) can be derived from the hypomeral ridge. The presence of these ‘false sutures’ is variable not only within a genus (e.g.,
Mimogonellus
, but also genera from outside Osoriini ), and also within a species. For instance, in the type specimens of
Mm. leleupi
, the ‘false sutures’ are more distinct in SEM images in the female paralectotype ( Fig. 16 ), otherwise not differing much from the male syntypes , which have poorly visible traces of this structure ( Figs 14–15 ). In fact, the visibility of the weakly developed ‘false notosternal sutures’ depends on the angle of observation, as seen in Figs 17–24 showing two male type specimens. Posteriorly, the ‘false suture’ does not reach the procoxal cavity, as the true notosternal suture would, but instead the ridge runs around the outer margin of the procoxal fissure and is clearly continuous with the poorly developed hypomeral ridge ( Figs 21–24 ) that divides hypomeron into the outer impressed region and the inner subtriangular postcoxal hypomeral lobe. If the ‘sutures’ are clearly visible on the surface under a stereomicroscope, in order to verify whether these are true notosternal sutures or only a superficial ‘false sutures’, examination of cleared specimens either in ethanol, glycerol, or embedded in a solid medium under a compound microscope is necessary.

The sulcus indicated in Figs 8 and 10 as ‘?hs’ is most likely a result of the fusion of hypostomal sutures forming a single median longitudinal groove on the ventral surface of the head. As observed in cleared specimens under a compound microscope, the sites where the posterior tentorial arms originate (without developed posterior tentorial pits) are placed behind this sulcus, in the posteriormost region of the head capsule. The gula is vestigial and situated (as in all insects) behind the posterior tentorial arms; in Osoriini the gular plate is usually hidden under the anterior margin of the prosternum. Consequently, the genae strongly expanding mesally reduce the posterior region of the submentum (situated between the hypostomal sutures) to a single longitudinal apodeme, externally marked by the groove.

The present work is an advanced step of research on the Afrotropical fauna of Osoriinae and it does not exhaust problems related to
Mimogonellus
. Diagnoses of genera within Osoriini seem based on weak or largely overlapping characters, and at least some are unclear and do not allow for unambiguous assignement of specimens to a genus. Most genera are primarily defined by features related to the shapes of body parts that in other staphylinids are highly variable within a genus. One of the examples illustrating the ‘
Mimogonellus
problem’ is
Thoracogonus Coiffait.
The description and illustration of this genus (
) are not sufficient to verify the status of
Thoracogonus
, but it seems that the only differences in relation to
Mimogonellus
are the shape of the parameres and the carinate lateral elytral margins. This is another candidate for a junior synonym of
Mimogonellus
(especially that similarly shaped parameres can be find also in
Mm. collarti
and
Mm. sparsepunctatus Fagel
). Also
Edapholotrochus
, a South African endogean genus, may be identical with
Mimogonellus
; they share the structure of the aedeagus, modifications of the sternite VIII and tergite X in males, and moniliform antennae.

sec.title: Acknowledgments
sec.p:
We would like to express our gratitude to Petr Baňař (MMBC), Giulio Cuccodoro (MHNG), Yvonnick Gerard (RBINS), Stéphane Hanot (RMCA), Toshiharu Mita (ELKU), Harald Schillhammer (NHMW), Bernd Jaeger (MNHB), and Yu-Lingzi Zhou (ANIC) for loaning specimens to study. Anna Siudzińska (Bioimaging Laboratory, PORT Polish Center for Technology Development, Wrocław) is thanked for taking the SEM images. We also thank Matthias Borer (Natural History Museum, Basel) for taking images of the holotype of
Madegassosorius keiseri Scheerpeltz, and Peter Hlaváč
(Natural History Museum, Prague ) for his help in translating Coiffait’s key.
